title: Luxury apartment inside country home where the Queen Mother went to live for sale
text:
Advertisement

A luxury apartment inside a country home where the Queen Mother went to live with her brother during the First World War has go on the market for almost £500,000.

Olive House near Uckfield, East Sussex, was home to Elizabeth Bowes Lyon's brother Fergus in the early 20th century.

At the outbreak of the First World War his younger sister, then aged just 14, was sent to live with him after her family home - Glamis Castle in Angus, Scotland - became a hospital.

The arrangement came nine years before she married King George VI and 12 years before she gave birth to Elizabeth II.

The country flat, located near Uckfield, East Sussex, was home to Elizabeth Bowes Lyon's brother Fergus in the early 20th century. The stylish apartment has exposed wooden beams and a roomy living area

The property boasts resplendent views of the East Sussex countryside for miles around as well as a close proximity to the town of Uckfield

The bedroom in the property is spacious with plenty of light coming in from the balcony area, of which the property boasts three

The front of the spectacular Olive House. The three bedroom flat that is currently on the market is on the whole of the top floor of the building and enjoys commanding views across the surrounding countryside

One of the most stylish aspects of the luxury apartment is the large open plan kitchen with its own balcony

During her time living at the house, the Queen Consort was bridesmaid at her brother's wedding when he married Lady Christian Norah Dawson-Damer.

He served as a captain during the war and was a member of the the 8th Battalion.

He was killed in France at the Battle of the Hohenzollern Redoubt in 1915, just two months after his daughter Rosemary was born.

Since his death Olive House, which was originally built in 1710, has had a string of different owners.

It was converted into apartments around several years ago but still retains it's striking period exterior.

The three bedroom flat that is currently on the market is on the whole of the top floor of the building and enjoys commanding views across the surrounding countryside.

Olive House is nestled in beautiful grounds and boasts spectacular views of the East Sussex countryside. The home belonged to Elizabeth Bowes Lyon's brother Fergus in the early 20th century

The historic home is on the market with estate agents Hamptons International Sales who have given it a guide price of £485,000. It includes a magnificent drawing room and country-style breakfast room

The majestic front of Oliver House, with plenty of privacy. Outside, there is access to a double garage for parking and the attractive grounds

The views can be enjoyed from any of the property's three balconies.

Outside, there is access to a double garage for parking and the attractive grounds.

The historic home is on the market with estate agents Hamptons International Sales who have given it a guide price of £485,000.

A spokesman for the agents said: 'This was the home of the Queen Mother's brother - Fergus Bowes.

'She lived there in 1914, when she moved in with her brother during the start of the war to leave her family home which became a hospital.

'During her time there she was also, bridesmaid at his wedding when he married Lady Christian Norah Dawson-Damer.

'He unfortunately died the year after in WWI, just 10 days after his first wedding anniversary.

'Highlights of the property include the magnificent drawing room, the country-style kitchen-breakfast room.'

Anyone interested in the apartment should contact Hamptons directly.
